title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Panmure House, a large plain-looking edifice on the left going down, was originally a residence of the Panmure family ; it more recently was inhabited by Adam Smith, the author of "the Wealth of Nations," who died in 1790, and was buried in the Canongate churchyard, where Dugald Stewart is also interred.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Adam Smith spent the last twelve years of his life in Panmure House, Panmure Close, 129 Canongate. This edifice still stands on the right-hand side of the close, numbered 15, as one enters from the Canongate.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: It is now altered, and brought into juxtaposition with the coarse details of an iron-foundry, yet still is not without some traits of its original style. The name of Panmure House takes the mind back to the Earls of Panmure, the fourth of whom lost title and estates for his concern in the affair of 1715 ; but I am not certain of any earlier proprietor of this family than William Maule, nephew of the attainted earl, created Earl of Panmui-e as an Irish title in 1743, granduncle of

title: Romances of the old town of Edinburgh /
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: T was the custom at one time in Edinburgh for the proprietors of large self-contained houses to give them the names of the properties they had in the country — hence our Panmure House, Tweeddale Court, and so forth — and among them there was Gorthley House, of which no vestige now remains ; nay, we are by no means sure where it was situated, beyond the fact that it was somewhere in the Canongate, but gone as it is according to the law of change, its name will always be associated with the law-plea Bruce versus Bruce, which contained the germ of the little romance we are now to relate in our way. And to begin in order, we take the state of matters at the time when the plea began.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: * Some miles to the west of Arbroatli is Panmure House, upon wMch llie present Earl lias made great ehangts and improvements, and those ^^ho have a remembrance of the former venerable building, must now imagine it completely encased in the new. In the interior the old building has been turned to good accuimt, and the huge ball-room and the ])rincipal old oaken staircase and balus- trade—the latter formed of beautifully carved oaken pillars— still remain.
